creator: sambukkaa@hotmail.com
text:
The Server just restarts without any warning after a call to a none existing 
perl file (usually by hackers trying to call the awstats.pl)
and the error.log file gets filled with lines like below:

[Sat Dec 17 19:57:40 2005] [error] <none>=HASH(0x4a62ce0)
[Sat Dec 17 19:57:40 2005] [error] <none>=HASH(0x44c458c)

What that means? do we need the error.log file getting filled with hundreds of 
lines like those?

creator: sambukkaa@hotmail.com
text:
yes, mod_perl is activated.
I have to add that beside that problem, eveything works perfectly

here is a cutout of the all activated Modules:

LoadFile "C:/Perl/bin/perl58.dll"
LoadModule perl_module modules/mod_perl.so
LoadModule access_module modules/mod_access.so
LoadModule actions_module modules/mod_actions.so
LoadModule alias_module modules/mod_alias.so
LoadModule asis_module modules/mod_asis.so
LoadModule auth_module modules/mod_auth.so
LoadModule autoindex_module modules/mod_autoindex.so
LoadModule cgi_module modules/mod_cgi.so
LoadModule dir_module modules/mod_dir.so
LoadModule env_module modules/mod_env.so
LoadModule imap_module modules/mod_imap.so
LoadModule include_module modules/mod_include.so
LoadModule isapi_module modules/mod_isapi.so
LoadModule log_config_module modules/mod_log_config.so
LoadModule mime_module modules/mod_mime.so
LoadModule rewrite_module modules/mod_rewrite.so
LoadModule negotiation_module modules/mod_negotiation.so
LoadModule setenvif_module modules/mod_setenvif.so
LoadModule userdir_module modules/mod_userdir.so
LoadModule php5_module "c:/php/php5apache2.dll"
LoadModule logio_module modules/mod_logio.so

System: Windows 2000 Advanced Server + last service packs
Server: apache_2.0.55-win32-x86-no_ssl
No virtual Hosts
PHP Version:  5.1.0
mysql Version 5.0.16 (installed on the same machine)
Upstream: ~ 1 GB per day

Well, if you need more information just ask :)
creator: sambukkaa@hotmail.com
rpluem@apache.org
text:
Well that was my guess. This message seems to come from mod_perl. So the root
cause for this can be found in mod_perl. Please report this problem to the
mod_perl developers
(http://perl.apache.org/docs/2.0/user/help/help.html#Reporting_Problems)
